Man gets kicked out of all you can eat buffet for eating too much
Lifestyle
DC Correspondent
1 Sep 2017 7:58 AM
Massachusetts man is suing Golden Corral Corporation for being kicked out of establishment for eating 50 pounds of food.
The welfare recipient was expelled after he spent more than seven hours on site eating a whopping 50 pounds of food, alone. (Photo: Pixabay)
Albert Flemming, from Massachusetts is suing Golden Corral Corporation for $2million for false advertising after he was thrown out of one of the chain’s restaurants by its employees.
According to witnesses, the welfare recipient was expelled after he spent more than seven hours on site eating a whopping 50 pounds of food, alone.
Despite advertising, an ‘all you can eat’ buffet, the manager seemingly lost patience at some point telling the now disgruntled customer that his meal would be free but he has to leave.
The manager’s intervention angered Flemming, and after a brief altercation between the two, he was thrown out of the establishment. Flemming went on to call the police and filed a complaint against the restaurant and says he will hold the employeed accountable for their actions.
As reported by the website 8Shit, Flemming told reporters that it was a serious injustice and he was deeply insulted. He went on to add, “With my income, I rarely go to restaurants, so I tried...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: Deccan Chronicle is an Indian English-language daily newspaper that offers news across various topics. It has a decent reputation for reporting but has faced criticisms in the past regarding sensationalism. While it typically presents factual news, caution is advised regarding content accuracy.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence provides specific details about the man's name, what he was doing at the buffet, the number of pounds of food he consumed, and the actions taken by the management (asking him to leave without charging him). It is very relevant to the lawsuit and clarifies the claim of false advertising, making it highly pertinent.

content.content:
http://dailyheadlines.net/2016/02/man-sues-golden-corral-for-2-million-dollars-wait-till-you-hear-why/
A big, fat guy went to Golden Corral for 7 hours, ate between 50-70 pounds of food, and then the manager asked him to leave, without charging him - and now he’s suing them saying their “All you can eat” buffet is false advertising. He goes on to say that with him limited income (he is on welfare) he rarely gets to eat out so he was trying to get his money’s worth.
If you’ve eaten the equivalent of a middle school student in buffet food, you’ve gotten your whole town’s money’s worth.
I’m just glad our welfare system is working as intended and the people that really need the assistance are getting it… Sarcasm
7 hours. I wonder if he had a game boy or something with him? Even if I strove to be the biggest, fattest slob I could, I think I’d get bored if it was just eating for 7 hours.The case will probably get thrown out, these kinds generally do. Especially since he wasn’t charged.
Erm, the all you can eat does not mean all you can eat fatso!! My wife worked for Old Country Buffet corporate and they do have a legal definition built into the All You Can Eat phrase. Managers were always asking customers to leave.
Who the F#$^ can eat ...[Content truncated]

There are minimal checks for accuracy, making it less reliable for fact-checking news articles or serious claims like lawsuits.

The information directly relates to the lawsuit, grounding the claim of false advertising in the actual events that transpired between the man and the restaurant.

Query1.title: Could you sue an ''all you can eat'' restaurant if they throw you out ...
Query1.snippet: Aug 30, 2023 ... Can someone get kicked out of an all you can eat Buffet for eating too much food like Homer Simpson was on The Simpsons? I personally have not, ...

content.content:
[Content truncated]... principle. Some people take legal action to end a bad practice rather than get financial compensation.
By the way, even in the US, anyone can’t
Continue Reading
Yes, but the cost of the lawsuit would be more than your loss from not being able to eat all that you want. Because the loss would only be for a partial loss, not the whole loss.
In addition, the restaurant might have had some clauses when you paid. Such as a time limit (ie closing time), or might be able to remove you if you are being wasteful of the food, such as not finishing one plate before going for the next one.
!
But often these cases are about the principle. Some people take legal action to end a bad practice rather than get financial compensation.
By the way, even in the US, anyone can’t just sue anyone they want. What they can do though is apply to the courts to get leave to sue someone.
Also, if you want the money, you don’t sue, you threaten to sue.
Upvote ·
94

Can you be kicked out of a restaurant for eating too much of an “all you can eat buffet”?
At least in Indian restaurants, it doesn't work like that. Otherwise, during my college days, when I had the appetite of a monster, I would have got kicked out of every single buffet place I had been to.
!

Continue Reading
At least in Indian restaurants, it doesn't work like that. Otherwise, during my college days, when I had the appetite of a monster, I would have got kicked out of every single buffet place I had been to.
!
When restaurants advertise themselves as an 'all you can eat’ buffet, they stick to it. Yes, you cannot pack your food, you cannot share the meal with two or more people, but there's no end limit to how much you will be allowed to eat. If you want the starters to keep on coming for two hours straight, they will do so. If you want to have three plates of mutton biryani all by yourself, nobody will raise an objection; you will be gladly welcomed for your fourth plate.
!
Restaurants smartly keep the price tag of their buffet taking everything into consideration...[Content truncated]

Apparently, the phrase "all you can eat" doesn't mean you can sit there for 7 hours and consume 70 pounds of food...  
But, it must mean $2 million bucks if they pull your plate from you. Clearly this guy was hungry.  
MAN SUES GOLDEN CORRAL FOR 2 MILLION DOLLARS..WAIT TILL YOU HEAR WHY  
A fifty one year old Springfield, Massachusetts man is suing Golden Corral because he bought the all you can eat buffet but was kicked out before he was finished. Despite the fact that they let him have what he ate for free, Mr Fleming (Or Mr Flemmings, name is uncertain) is suing them for 2 million dollars for false advertisement. Golden Corral offers an all you can eat buffet. Mr Fleming says that not only was he still hungry but:  
“It’s a serious injustice, and I am deeply insulted! With my income, I rarely go to the restaurant, so I try to get as much as I can for my money when I do. This was the worst experience I have ever had in a restaurant. Not only did they kick me out while I was still hungry, but they looked at me like I was disgusting, like I was not worthy of eating there! It’s unacceptable, and I demand a compensation!”  
By now, you are probably wondering what you are missing. Mr Fleming had stayed at the buffet for over seven hours and consumed 50 to 70 pounds of food.  
]  
Normally, I would consider this an open and shut case as he purchased the lunch buffet which lasts only 5 1/2 hours and he was actually eating the supper buffet. However, this being Massachusetts, common sense does not apply. Top Golden Corral executives claim the decision to toss Mr Fleming was the act of an over zealous manager and they say...[Content truncated]

QA.Question: What specific actions did Golden Corral take against the man after his seven-hour visit that led to the lawsuit?
QA.Answer:
After the man's seven-hour visit to Golden Corral, the specific actions that led to the lawsuit included the following:

1. **Expulsion from the Establishment**: Albert Flemming, the plaintiff, was ultimately expelled from the Golden Corral after he had consumed approximately 50 pounds of food during his lengthy stay. The management intervened and asked him to leave, citing a loss of patience regarding the duration of his visit at an all-you-can-eat buffet, which led to significant frustration on his part.

2. **Manager's Remarks**: During the incident, the manager explicitly told Flemming that his meal would be complimentary, but that he must leave the premises. This statement further aggravated the situation and contributed to the altercation between Flemming and the staff. The encounter escalated to a point where he felt wronged and insulted, prompting him to take legal action against Golden Corral for what he described as false advertising regarding their buffet offer.

3. **Call to Authorities**: After being thrown out, Flemming called the police and filed a complaint against the restaurant. This action indicates the extent of his dissatisfaction and the seriousness with which he viewed the treatment he received, leading him to seek accountability for the actions of the employees at Golden Corral.

In summary, Flemming's lawsuit stems from being asked to leave after exceeding a typical dining duration at a buffet, coupled with his perception of being treated unjustly despite the restaurant's advertised promise of an all-you-can-eat experience.
